title: Get to know the tiles
text:
Click through the flashcards below to learn about the different tiles.



There are the five types of Mahjong tiles:

Numbers

Numeric Tiles + Dragons
These tiles come in 3 suits: Dots (circles), Bams (bamboo), and Craks (characters). Think of each suit like a playing-card suit‚Äîwith a ‚Äúface card‚Äù in the form of a Dragon.

title: Game Play
text:
Now that you know the tiles, the deal, the Charleston, and the card‚Äîit‚Äôs time to actually play the game!

The Flow of a Turn
Each player takes turns in counter-clockwise order, beginning with East. A turn has two main steps:

Draw a Tile

On your turn, you must draw one tile.

You can draw from the wall (the normal stack of tiles) OR call a discard if it completes a set for your hand.

Discard a Tile

After drawing, you must discard one tile face-up into the center.

Your hand always returns to 13 tiles (or 14 if you‚Äôre declaring Mahjong).




Calling Discards
When someone discards a tile, other players have the chance to call it:

Pung/Kong/Quint: If the discard completes your set of 3, 4, or 5 identical tiles, you can call immediately.

Mahjong!: If the discard gives you a complete hand from the card, you can declare Mahjong and win the round.

Priority: If multiple players want the same discard, the one declaring Mahjong always takes priority. Otherwise, the player closest in turn order to the discarder gets it.


Pro tip: You can only call for a pair if it completes a winning Mahjong hand. Otherwise, pairs must be drawn naturally.



Winning a Hand
To declare Mahjong, your hand must:

Match exactly one of the combinations shown on the card

Contain 14 tiles (13 plus the winning tile)

Once you win, you lay down your tiles for all players to see and the hand ends.


Ending Without a Winner
If all tiles in the wall are used up before anyone declares Mahjong, the round ends in a wall game. Players reset and start a new hand, rotating the dealer position (East).

section: The Four Winds Around Your Table
text:
The Four Winds Around Your Table
American Mahjong is played by four players, each representing one of the cardinal wind directions.
East - The dealer and starting position
South - Sits to East‚Äôs right
West - Sits across from East
North - Sits to East‚Äôs left
Fun Fact: The wind seating doesn‚Äôt follow a traditional compass layout. In Mahjong, the winds follow Asian cardinal points and have traditional associations with seasons (East/Spring, South/Summer, West/Autumn, North/Winter), which may explain why the arrangement differs from a standard compass.














The wind positions rotate throughout the game, giving each player a turn as the dealer. Don‚Äôt worry about memorizing everything now, we‚Äôll cover the significance of these positions as we progress through the lessons.

title: The Card
text:
The American Mahjong card is your guide to winning hands. You can purchase this year‚Äôs official card from the National Mah Jongg League. Each line shows exactly what 14 tiles you need to win, using shorthand symbols and helpful notes.



Basic Structure
Every line on the card represents one complete winning hand. The card is organized into different categories, and each hand shows:

Shorthand notation (the tile abbreviations)
Notes (additional details about requirements)
Point values (how much the hand is worth)
Concealed (whether the hand must be concealed, incidated by a C)




Shorthand
The card uses these standard abbreviations:

1-9: Numbered tiles (any suit: dots, bams, or craks)
D: Dragon
0: Soap (white dragon, can be paired with any suit)
N, E, W, S: Wind tiles (North, East, West, South)
F: Flower tiles



Examples
11 22 333 444 5555
This means you need 2 ones, 2 twos, 3 threes, 3 fours, and 4 fives
FFFF 11 22 333 DDD
This means you need 4 flowers, 2 ones, 2 twos, 3 threes, and 3 dragons



Essential Vocabulary
Understanding these terms is crucial for reading the card:

Pair: 2 identical tiles
Pung: 3 identical tiles

Kong: 4 identical tiles
Quint: 5 identical tiles




Reading the Notes
The notes next to each line give you critical information:
Suit Requirements

‚ÄúSame suit‚Äù = All numbered tiles must be from the same suit
‚ÄúAny 3 suits‚Äù = Use tiles from exactly 3 different suits
‚Äú2 suits‚Äù = Use tiles from exactly 2 suits

Special Conditions

‚ÄúX‚Äù = The pungs (sets of 3), kongs (sets of 4), or quints (sets of 5) can be called from the discards
‚ÄúC‚Äù = Conceled. NO tiles cannot be called from discards
‚ÄúConsecutive numbers‚Äù = Numbers must be in order (like 1-2-3)



Example
FFFF 11 22 333 DDD (Any 3 Consec. Nos. with Matching Dragons)
This means you do not need exactly 11 22 333, but you can use any 3 consecutive numbers (i.e.¬†44 55 666 or 77 88 999 would also work!). The dragons must match the suit, (i.e.¬†if you numbers are all bams, you must use the green dragons, if your numbers are all craks you must use the red dragon, if your numbers are all dots you must use the white dragon (soap!)).




Color Coding
When numbered tiles appear in the same color on the card, they must all be from the same suit.
Different colors mean you must have different suits for those tiles.
This visual system helps you quickly identify suit requirements at a glance.


Example
22 44 44 666 8888 (Any 3 Suits)
This means that the suit for the 22 and 44 must match, the suit for the 44 666 must match (and be different from the 22 44 suit), and the 8888 must be in the third suit.



Common Card Sections
The hands are grouped into sections that appear year after year:
{Year}: Hands using the current year with numbered tiles and soaps (e.g.¬†2025)
2468: Hands with only even numbers
Any Like Numbers: All numbers are the same (e.g., all 3s)
Math Sections: Some cards include multiplication/addition themes (e.g., FF 1111 + 6666 = 7777)
Quints: Hands including 5-of-a-kind groupings
Consecutive Runs: Numbers in increasing order (e.g., 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
13579: Hands with only odd numbers
Winds and Dragons: Hands featuring mostly winds and dragons
369: Hands using the numbers 3, 6, and 9
Singles and Pairs: Hands with only single tiles and pairs


How to Use the Card

Pick a category that matches tiles you‚Äôre collecting
Read the shorthand to see what tiles you need
Check the notes for specific requirements
Count to 14 to verify it‚Äôs a complete hand

The combination of shorthand + notes tells you exactly what you need to win!

Pro tip: Make sure to read the notes! Sometimes the pattern will use one number, but the notes specify that multiple numbers qualify.
